sub_topic: Probability of a certain type of environmental event occurring in a region
message_1: In a certain region, the probability of the occurrence of a forest fire in a year is 0.05. What is the probability that the region will have at least one forest fire in the next 5 years?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the complementary probability. The complementary probability of having at least one forest fire in the next 5 years is the probability of having no forest fires in the next 5 years.

The probability of not having a forest fire in a year is 1 - 0.05 = 0.95.

Since the events are independent, the probability of not having a forest fire in the next 5 years is the product of the probabilities of not having a forest fire in each year:

P(no fires in 5 years) = 0.95 * 0.95 * 0.95 * 0.95 * 0.95 = 0.95^5 ≈ 0.7737809375

Now, we can find the complementary probability of having at least one forest fire in the next 5 years:

P(at least one fire in 5 years) = 1 - P(no fires in 5 years) ≈ 1 - 0.7737809375 ≈ 0.2262190625

So, the probability that the region will have at least one forest fire in the next 5 years is approximately 0.2262 or 22.62%.
